overview_of_class: This course focuses on macroeconomic aspects of development economics, and deals mainly with historical and long term patterns of economic development. This is such a fundamental issue in economics that Adam Smith even made it the title of his book, "The Wealth of Nations." The main questions we ask are "How can economies grow or fail to grow?" "What explains the difference in the income levels and growth performances across countries?" No one can claim to have the answer to these difficult questions (and don't trust anyone who claims to know the answer). However, economic theories tell us what are important determinants of long run growth and development performances. More specifically, we will discuss the roles of investment (i.e., physical capital accumulation), of education (i.e., human capital accumulation), of technological change (i.e., knowledge capital accumulation through innovation and R&D), of income distribution, of population growth and demographic change, and others.

overview_of_class:
How can economies grow rich? And how may economies fail to grow rich?
These are fundamental questions in economics. Even Adam Smith alluded to them in the title of his
book, "The Wealth of Nations." These broad questions are the main focus of this course. No one can
claim to have the answer to these difficult questions. However, economic theories can inform us on
some important determinants of long-run growth patterns and development performances. In this
course, we will cover some of the leading theories proposed to understand different aspects of long-run
growth and development: Saving and capital accumulation, technological change, structural change,
demographic transition, income distribution, imperfect credit markets, etc. (see the preliminary list of
topics below)
Detailed Contents of the Class (Preliminary)
1. Facts and Measurement
2. Traditional Theories of Economic Growth (Harrod-Domar, Solow)
3. New Growth Theories (Human Capital, Endogenous Technological Progress)
4. History, Expectations and Development (Complementarities, Increasing Returns and
Poverty traps, some trade)
5. Credit Markets (Alternative micro underpinnings and related theories)
6. Inequality and Growth (Measurement, Kuznets Hypothesis, Interaction with Credit Mkts)
7. Population Growth and Economic Development (Demographic Transition, Unified
Growth Theory)
8. International Linkages: Trade and Financial Markets (time permitting)
9. Political Economy of Growth (time permitting)

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Economics 310-1, 310-2, 311-1, and 281 (or my permission). This course is
designed for economics majors, and I assume that you are familiar with the basic concepts and
tools in economics.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Mostly based on the two in-class quizzes, scheduled to be done in-class on 4/25 and 5/25, but
also the final exam (if need be). Quiz-I covers the materials in the first half (eight lectures) and
Quiz-II covers those in the second half (eight lectures). These quizzes count equally. Your
performance is judged based on the distribution of the simple sum of the numerical scores
of the two quizzes. The students who perform well enough in these two quizzes, meaning that they
deserve a C or better are exempt from the final exam. Those who do not perform well enough in these
two quizzes are given the opportunity to improve their final grade to a C by taking the final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Development Economics by Debraj Ray; Princeton University Press, 1998. ISBN-13: 978-0691017068

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: The Mystery of Economic Growth by Elhanan Helpman, 2004. ISBN-13: 9780674015722.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
In this course, we will not discuss much on the economic institutions and conditions that prevail
in/are specific of many developing countries. These questions are analyzed in Econ 326.
